content: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS Published: April 19, 2009 """http://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/20/business/20bailout.html?hp WASHINGTON — President Obama’s top economic advisers have determined that they can shore up the nation’s banking system without having to ask Congress for more money any time soon, according to administration officials. In a significant shift, White House and Treasury Department officials now say they can stretch what is left of the $700 billion financial bailout fund further than they had expected a few months ago, simply by converting the government’s existing loans to the nation’s 19 biggest banks into common stock. Converting those loans to common shares would turn the federal aid into available capital for a bank — and give the government a large ownership stake in return. While the option appears to be a quick and easy way to avoid a confrontation with Congressional leaders wary of putting more money into the banks, some critics would consider it a back door to nationalization, since the government could become the largest shareholder in several banks.

In a significant shift, White House and Treasury Department officials now say they can stretch what is left of the $700 billion financial bailout fund further than they had expected a few months ago, simply by converting the government’s existing loans to the nation’s 19 biggest banks into common stock. Converting those loans to common shares would turn the federal aid into available capital for a bank — and give the government a large ownership stake in return. While the option appears to be a quick and easy way to avoid a confrontation with Congressional leaders wary of putting more money into the banks, some critics would consider it a back door to nationalization, since the government could become the largest shareholder in several banks.
title: U.S. May Convert Bailouts To Common Stock: B

Let alone the loans they gave to the unqualified My bank showed me where allthis thieft of our money thru the banking system now costs me 1.452 higher on the interest rate. Where is all the money and we put one person in jail. Everyone that wrote one of the loans or paper buyouts should serve 10 years each. And now we are going to trust the Government to be the largest shareholder?????????????

content: The plan to convert government loan funds into common stock is risky and they'll have to be very careful as to which companies have their TARP funds converted to stock - but if it works, then the TARP money could be recovered (and then some) far quicker than anticipated and we might actually make a profit off of the whole mess.

title: U.S. May Convert Bailouts To Common Stock: B

content: Seems to me that such a conversion of TARP funds to shares would set up a huge conflict of interest for the government ... Should it happen, I would hope that that conflict is partially minimized by taking non-voting shares.

content: There's a bad joke about the 'old' homeless wanting to get away from the 'new' homeless by building their own tent city out in the boonies. But the rule will be no hi-tech tents. "Are you getting a TARP loan?", another asks. No we're using real tarps. I'm still trying to figure out what so bad about giving all this money to ordinary people. Let them claim it as income and if they are living well tax it back off them. It will stimulate the economy a lot more than letting the few rich convert dud shares into cash. At least they could buy some decent tenting equipment, and food. >from New America Media: Tarp Nation Squatter villages arise from the ashes of the West's booms and busts Posted: Mar 29, 2009 Editor's Note: Everywhere, Fresno, Calif., to the struggling casino district of Reno, Nev., and the upscale suburbs of Washington state, tent cities and shantytowns with names like Taco Flat have sprung up to house the poor and dispossessed. These roving, ramshackle neighborhoods were part of the American cityscape long before the stock market nosedived, and they are unlikely to disappear when prosperity returns. FRESNO, Calif. -- Marie and Francisco Caro needed a home after they married, but like many people in California's Central Valley, they didn't have enough money to sign a lease or take out a mortgage. They were tired of sleeping on separate beds in crowded homeless shelters, so they found a slice of land alongside the Union Pacific Railroad tracks in downtown Fresno. The soil was sandy and dry, prone to rising up into clouds when the autumn winds came. All around, farm equipment factories and warehouses loomed out of the dust, their walls coarse and sun-bleached like desert mountainsides. Even a strong person could wither in a place like this, but if they wanted to build a home, nobody was likely to stop them. So Marie and Francisco gathered scrap wood and took their chances. They raised their tarp roof high like a steeple, then walled off the world with office cubicle dividers. Thieves stayed outside and so did the wind, and the sound of the passing freight trains softened. When I visited the Caros in January, a fire burned in an overturned oil barrel, warming the cool air, and fresh-cut Christmas tree boughs hung on the walls for decoration. While Francisco chopped wood, Marie, 43, confided that she wants to live somewhere else. All she needs is a modest place with a sink and a gas stove, she said, maybe even a little television for watching church services on Sundays. ............(more)
